paragraphs.body: Movie-Moron is not a reliable source to cite for factual assertions. It's a blog with an explicit disclaimer "Due to the amount of speculation, site should be read for entertainment purposes only." Further there is no attribution to the assertion in the blog (which isn't even gramatically correct "Paramount want a worldwide take...."). This appears to be nothing more than a fabrication on the blog author's part based on ignorance. By way of example box office receipts don't equate to return on Paramount's investment. There are these things called "movie theaters" that take significant percentage of the receipts. The section as a whole relies far too much on Movie-Moron as a source and therefore should be deleted or rewritten with citation of valid sources. Likewise any reference to a 280 million box office gross as a thresshold for greenlighting production on a second movie should be deleted unless someone can cite a reliable source.
section: Status Section needs deletion or complete rewrite with accurate sources

There are these things called "movie theaters" that take significant percentage of the receipts. Likewise any reference to a 280 million box office gross as a thresshold for greenlighting production on a second movie should be deleted unless someone can cite a reliable source.

paragraphs.body:
Woah! Where did you come from? I'm wondering though: did you actually read the article? I've put several disclaimers in there saying that 280 Million isn't the magical number we thought it was... if that's not good enough for you you can just edit the article yourself... it's really not that hard.
We know about movie theatres you don't need to be an ass about it. In fact like i just said we know 280 isn't a magic number, and liek i said if you read the article you'd know that... Just remember that if you're going to make an argument you should provide facts and not big words (you have both... but the facts aren't solid) if you think the article relies too much on Movie-moron then feel free to edit it, that is the whole point of the wiki after all! ${link_0} (${link_1} • ${link_2}) 01:01, September 30, 2010 (UTC)

paragraphs.body: Okay, this article needs serious help-well all of our film articles do really. But seriously. There are way too many external links and the references are being ignored in favor of them. Honestly, the FAQ belongs more on a blog than on the article, it makes the page look very unprofessional and is filled with too much speculation and references from other movies-movies that do not have to do with TLA. Can we please fix this?-- ${link_0} ${link_1}・${link_2} 02:56, February 28, 2011 (UTC)

paragraphs.body: I suggest the FAQ be removed. We are not a place to list reasons why the movie will be green lighted, nor are we a place to tell people,"These are the reasons it will be green lighted!" It honestly makes the page unprofessional. It mpbelongs on a blog. We are an encyclopedia, not a place to document why this movie may be green lighted.-- ${link_0} ${link_1}・${link_2} 06:41, March 31, 2011 (UTC)

paragraphs.body: I'm cool with that. To be honest, I think it touches upon a bigger question of where a FAQ belongs on a wikia site: if the information is solid then why even structure it as a FAQ? If it isn't definitive, shouldn't it belong in a forum or something? If everybody has their own answers, why not put it in a blogpost? On the other hand, a blogpost can't be edited by others, and a userpage has no comment section. I prefer some kind of mechanism to improve the "quality" of the comments, e.g. a Forum with a comment section enabled where comment page is used to keep track of the "score". This FAQ is a failed experiment. Let's see if fits better a blogpost. ${link_0} (${link_1} • ${link_2}) 10:04, March 31, 2011 (UTC)
paragraphs.text: I'm cool with that. To be honest, I think it touches upon a bigger question of where a FAQ belongs on a wikia site: if the information is solid then why even structure it as a FAQ? If it isn't definitive, shouldn't it belong in a forum or something? If everybody has their own answers, why not put it in a blogpost? On the other hand, a blogpost can't be edited by others, and a userpage has no comment section. I prefer some kind of mechanism to improve the "quality" of the comments, e.g. a Forum with a comment section enabled where comment page is used to keep track of the "score". This FAQ is a failed experiment. Let's see if fits better a blogpost. Hasdi (talk • contribs) 10:04, March 31, 2011 (UTC)

paragraphs.body: I have been working recently to rewrite this article to remove a lot of the speculative or subjective information that has been included; I have included my edited version of the article in ${link_0}, though I by no means suggest this as the "final" version. To give a brief summary of the changes I have made:
section: Significant changes and removal of speculation
paragraphs.text: I have been working recently to rewrite this article to remove a lot of the speculative or subjective information that has been included; I have included my edited version of the article in this sandbox page, though I by no means suggest this as the "final" version. To give a brief summary of the changes I have made:

paragraphs.body:
Removed all suggestions of who would be involved in the movie (the cast, producers etc.). This to me is all entirely subjective and given that the first film was 8 years ago now, we cannot assume the same people will be involved should a sequel be made.
 The aspects of casting I have kept are that Shyamalan wrote a draft (confirmed), that he wanted Toph to be asian (confirmed), that there was suggestions Chloe Grace Moretz should play the role (somewhat confirmed though needs more sources), and Milla Jovovich wanted a role (confirmed).
section: Significant changes and removal of speculation
paragraphs.text:
Removed all suggestions of who would be involved in the movie (the cast, producers etc.). This to me is all entirely subjective and given that the first film was 8 years ago now, we cannot assume the same people will be involved should a sequel be made.
 The aspects of casting I have kept are that Shyamalan wrote a draft (confirmed), that he wanted Toph to be asian (confirmed), that there was suggestions Chloe Grace Moretz should play the role (somewhat confirmed though needs more sources), and Milla Jovovich wanted a role (confirmed).

paragraphs.body: The aspects of casting I have kept are that Shyamalan wrote a draft (confirmed), that he wanted Toph to be asian (confirmed), that there was suggestions Chloe Grace Moretz should play the role (somewhat confirmed though needs more sources), and Milla Jovovich wanted a role (confirmed).
section: Significant changes and removal of speculation
paragraphs.text: The aspects of casting I have kept are that Shyamalan wrote a draft (confirmed), that he wanted Toph to be asian (confirmed), that there was suggestions Chloe Grace Moretz should play the role (somewhat confirmed though needs more sources), and Milla Jovovich wanted a role (confirmed).

paragraphs.body: Certain statements should be placed into the wider context; what I mean is what was planned for the movie years ago should not be taken as what will happen, and thus should be placed into the context of who made the suggestions or plans and when.
section: Significant changes and removal of speculation
